case_vignette: A 56-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of malaise, dysuria, blurred vision, and a painful, itchy rash. The rash began on her chest and face and spread to her limbs, palms, and soles. One week ago, she was diagnosed with trigeminal neuralgia and started on a new medicine. She appears ill. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F) and pulse is 110/min. Physical examination shows conjunctival injection and ulceration on the tongue and palate. There is no lymphadenopathy. Examination of the skin shows confluent annular, erythematous macules, bullae, and desquamation of the palms and soles. The epidermis separates when the skin is lightly stroked.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?

I've been feeling really unwell, experiencing discomfort when I urinate, my vision is blurry, and I've got this painful, itchy rash that started on my chest and face and has now spread to my arms and legs, and even the palms of my hands and the bottoms of my feet.
What is your age and sex?
I am a 56-year-old woman.
Do you have any medical history of autoimmune diseases or diabetes?
No, I don't have any history of autoimmune diseases or diabetes.
Do you take any medications for any other conditions?
Yes, I started taking a new medicine a week ago for facial pain.
What is the name of the new medication you started taking?
I don't remember the name of the new medicine.
Do you have any family history of skin conditions or allergies?
I haven't mentioned any family history of skin conditions or allergies.
**Final Diagnosis:** Stevens-Johnson Syndrome
